title: Theft (IPC Section 378)
description: Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of the possession of any person without that person's consent, moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft.
punishment: IPC Section 379: Imprisonment of up to 3 years, or fine, or both.

title: Hit and Run (Motor Vehicles Act Section 161)
description: Compensation for death or injury in hit and run cases. The law mandates compensation for victims of hit-and-run motor accidents.
punishment: Imprisonment, heavy fines, and seizure of vehicle depending on severity.

title: Punishment for Murder (IPC Section 302)
description: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: D.K. Basu Guidelines (Arrest Rights)
description: Guidelines that police must follow during arrest and detention: 1. Police must identify themselves clearly. 2. Memo of arrest must be prepared. 3. Family/friend must be informed. 4. Right to lawyer during interrogation.
punishment: Departmental action and contempt of court for police officers violating these.

title: Right to Education Act 2009
description: Every child between the ages of 6 to 14 years has the right to free and compulsory education.
punishment: Schools can be fined or derecognized for non-compliance.

title: Definition of State (Article 12)
description: Defines the term 'State' to include the Government, Parliament, State Legislatures, local authorities, and other bodies under government control for the purpose of enforcing Fundamental Rights.
punishment: Any violation of Fundamental Rights by the State can be challenged in court.

title: Laws Inconsistent with Fundamental Rights (Article 13)
description: Declares that any law inconsistent with or violating Fundamental Rights shall be void to the extent of such inconsistency.
punishment: Unconstitutional laws can be struck down by courts.

title: Equality Before Law (Article 14)
description: Ensures equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons within the territory of India.
punishment: Discriminatory actions can be challenged in High Court or Supreme Court.

title: Prohibition of Discrimination (Article 15)
description: Prohibits discrimination by the State on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
punishment: Discriminatory practices can be declared unconstitutional.

title: Equality in Public Employment (Article 16)
description: Guarantees equal opportunity for all citizens in matters of employment or appointment to public offices.
punishment: Unfair recruitment practices can be challenged in court.

title: Abolition of Untouchability (Article 17)
description: Abolishes untouchability in all forms and forbids its practice in any manner.
punishment: Punishable under the Protection of Civil Rights Act, 1955.

title: Abolition of Titles (Article 18)
description: Prohibits the State from conferring titles except military or academic distinctions.
punishment: Illegal titles have no constitutional validity.

title: Protection of Certain Freedoms (Article 19)
description: Guarantees freedoms of speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession subject to reasonable restrictions.
punishment: Unreasonable restrictions can be struck down by courts.

title: Protection in Criminal Convictions (Article 20)
description: Protects individuals from retrospective punishment, double jeopardy, and self-incrimination.
punishment: Illegal convictions can be quashed by courts.

title: Right to Life and Personal Liberty (Article 21)
description: No person shall be deprived of life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law. It includes dignity, privacy, health, and speedy justice.
punishment: Compensation and action against authorities for violations.

title: Right to Education (Article 21A)
description: Provides free and compulsory education to all children between 6 and 14 years of age.
punishment: State authorities and schools can be penalized for non-compliance.

title: Rights of Arrested Persons (Article 22)
description: Provides safeguards such as the right to be informed of grounds of arrest and the right to consult a lawyer.
punishment: Illegal detention can result in compensation and disciplinary action.

title: Prohibition of Human Trafficking and Forced Labour (Article 23)
description: Prohibits human trafficking, begar (forced labour), and other similar forms of exploitation.
punishment: Punishable under laws such as the Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act and Bonded Labour System (Abolition) Act.

title: Prohibition of Child Labour (Article 24)
description: Prohibits employment of children below 14 years of age in factories, mines, or hazardous occupations.
punishment: Punishable under the Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act.

title: Freedom of Religion (Article 25)
description: Guarantees freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, and health.
punishment: Unlawful restrictions can be struck down by courts.

title: Freedom to Manage Religious Affairs (Article 26)
description: Gives religious denominations the right to manage their own affairs in matters of religion.
punishment: State interference beyond constitutional limits can be challenged in court.

title: Freedom from Payment of Religious Taxes (Article 27)
description: Prohibits the State from compelling any person to pay taxes for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion.
punishment: Illegal taxation can be declared unconstitutional.

title: Theft (IPC Section 378)
description: Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of the possession of any person without that person's consent, moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft.
punishment: IPC Section 379: Imprisonment of up to 3 years, or fine, or both.

title: Hit and Run (Motor Vehicles Act Section 161)
description: Compensation for death or injury in hit and run cases. The law mandates compensation for victims of hit-and-run motor accidents.
punishment: Imprisonment, heavy fines, and seizure of vehicle depending on severity.

title: Punishment for Murder (IPC Section 302)
description: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: D.K. Basu Guidelines (Arrest Rights)
description: Guidelines that police must follow during arrest and detention: 1. Police must identify themselves clearly. 2. Memo of arrest must be prepared. 3. Family/friend must be informed. 4. Right to lawyer during interrogation.
punishment: Departmental action and contempt of court for police officers violating these.

title: Right to Education Act 2009
description: Every child between the ages of 6 to 14 years has the right to free and compulsory education.
punishment: Schools can be fined or derecognized for non-compliance.

title: Article 1 – Name and Territory of the Union
description: Declares India as a 'Union of States' and defines its territorial composition including states, union territories, and acquired territories.
impact: Establishes India’s political identity and territorial structure.

title: Article 2 – Admission or Establishment of New States
description: Empowers Parliament to admit new states into the Union or establish new states.
impact: Provides flexibility for expansion or reorganization of India’s territory.

title: Article 3 – Formation of New States and Alteration of Areas
description: Allows Parliament to form new states or alter boundaries, areas, or names of existing states.
impact: Enabled major state reorganizations and boundary changes.

title: Article 4 – Laws under Articles 2 and 3
description: Provides that laws made under Articles 2 and 3 may include supplemental provisions and are not considered constitutional amendments.
impact: Simplifies legal procedures for state reorganization.

title: Article 5 – Citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution
description: Defines who became citizens of India on 26 January 1950 based on domicile, birth, descent, or residence.
impact: Established initial citizenship framework at the time of independence.

title: Article 6 – Citizenship of persons migrated from Pakistan to India
description: Provides citizenship rights to migrants from Pakistan before and after 19 July 1948 with specific conditions and registration.
impact: Protected rights of refugees and migrants after partition.

title: Article 7 – Citizenship of persons migrated to Pakistan
description: Denied citizenship to those who migrated to Pakistan after partition unless they returned with a resettlement permit.
impact: Clarified citizenship status of partition migrants.

title: Article 8 – Citizenship of persons of Indian origin residing outside India
description: Allows persons of Indian origin living abroad to register as Indian citizens through diplomatic representatives.
impact: Maintained legal connection with Indian diaspora.

title: Article 9 – Voluntary acquisition of foreign citizenship
description: States that any person voluntarily acquiring foreign citizenship will lose Indian citizenship.
impact: Prohibited dual citizenship under the Constitution.

title: Article 10 – Continuance of citizenship
description: Ensures continued citizenship rights subject to laws made by Parliament.

title: Article 11 – Parliament’s power to regulate citizenship
description: Empowers Parliament to make laws regarding acquisition and termination of citizenship.
impact: Led to enactment of the Citizenship Act, 1955.

title: Definition of State (Article 12)
description: Defines the term 'State' to include the Government, Parliament, State Legislatures, local authorities, and other bodies under government control for the purpose of enforcing Fundamental Rights.
punishment: Any violation of Fundamental Rights by the State can be challenged in court.

punishment: Unconstitutional laws can be struck down by courts.

punishment: Discriminatory practices can be declared unconstitutional.

punishment: Illegal titles have no constitutional validity.

punishment: Unreasonable restrictions can be struck down by courts.

punishment: Illegal convictions can be quashed by courts.

punishment: Compensation and action against authorities for violations.

punishment: State authorities and schools can be penalized for non-compliance.

title: Rights of Arrested Persons (Article 22)

punishment: Illegal detention can result in compensation and disciplinary action.

title: Prohibition of Human Trafficking and Forced Labour (Article 23)
description: Prohibits human trafficking, begar (forced labour), and other similar forms of exploitation.
punishment: Punishable under laws such as the Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act and Bonded Labour System (Abolition) Act.

title: Prohibition of Child Labour (Article 24)
description: Prohibits employment of children below 14 years of age in factories, mines, or hazardous occupations.
punishment: Punishable under the Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act.

title: Freedom of Religion (Article 25)
description: Guarantees freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, and health.
punishment: Unlawful restrictions can be struck down by courts.

title: Freedom to Manage Religious Affairs (Article 26)
description: Gives religious denominations the right to manage their own affairs in matters of religion.
punishment: State interference beyond constitutional limits can be challenged in court.

title: Freedom from Payment of Religious Taxes (Article 27)
description: Prohibits the State from compelling any person to pay taxes for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion.
punishment: Illegal taxation can be declared unconstitutional.

title: Freedom from Religious Instruction (Article 28)
description: Prohibits religious instruction in educational institutions wholly funded by the State.
punishment: Violations can be challenged through constitutional remedies.

title: Protection of Cultural Rights (Article 29)
description: Protects the rights of any section of citizens to conserve their language, script, or culture.
punishment: Denial of admission or discrimination can be challenged in court.

title: Minority Educational Institutions (Article 30)
description: Gives minorities the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.
punishment: Unlawful interference by the State can be struck down.

title: Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)
description: Gives the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights through writs like Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto.
punishment: Courts can issue directions, orders, or compensation for violations.

title: Restriction of Rights for Armed Forces (Article 33)
description: Allows Parliament to restrict Fundamental Rights of armed forces, police, and intelligence agencies to ensure discipline.
punishment: Restrictions apply as per Parliamentary law.

title: Martial Law Provisions (Article 34)
description: Provides for restrictions on Fundamental Rights during the operation of martial law in any area.
punishment: Actions taken under valid martial law are protected as per law.

title: Legislation for Fundamental Rights (Article 35)
description: Empowers Parliament to make laws to give effect to the provisions of Fundamental Rights.
punishment: Violations are punishable under laws made by Parliament.

title: Definition of State for Directive Principles (Article 36)
description: Defines the term 'State' for the purposes of Directive Principles, similar to its meaning under Fundamental Rights.
punishment: Not enforceable by courts; acts as guiding principles.

title: Application of Directive Principles (Article 37)
description: Directive Principles are not enforceable by courts but are fundamental in the governance of the country.
punishment: No direct punishment; used for policy interpretation.

title: Social Order for Welfare of People (Article 38)
description: Directs the State to promote social, economic, and political justice and reduce inequalities.

title: Certain Principles of Policy (Article 39)
description: Ensures adequate livelihood, equal pay for equal work, protection of children, and prevention of concentration of wealth.
punishment: Implemented through labour and welfare laws.

title: Free Legal Aid and Justice (Article 39A)
description: Directs the State to provide free legal aid to ensure justice is not denied due to economic or other disabilities.
punishment: Implemented via Legal Services Authorities Act.

title: Organisation of Village Panchayats (Article 40)
description: Directs the State to organize village panchayats as units of self-government.

title: Right to Work, Education and Assistance (Article 41)
description: Directs the State to provide public assistance in cases of unemployment, old age, sickness, and disability.

title: Humane Conditions of Work and Maternity Relief (Article 42)
description: Directs the State to ensure humane working conditions and maternity relief for women.
punishment: Implemented through labour and maternity laws.

title: Living Wage for Workers (Article 43)
description: Directs the State to secure a living wage and decent standard of life for workers.

title: Participation of Workers in Management (Article 43A)
description: Directs the State to promote workers’ participation in the management of industries.
punishment: Implemented via industrial laws and policies.

title: Uniform Civil Code (Article 44)
description: Directs the State to secure a uniform civil code for all citizens throughout India.

title: Early Childhood Care and Education (Article 45)
description: Directs the State to provide early childhood care and education for children below six years.

title: Protection of Weaker Sections (Article 46)
description: Directs the State to promote educational and economic interests of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and other weaker sections.
punishment: Implemented through reservation and welfare laws.

title: Duty of the State to Raise Nutrition and Public Health (Article 47)
description: Directs the State to improve nutrition, living standards, public health, and prohibit intoxicating drinks and drugs.
punishment: Implemented via health and prohibition laws.

title: Organisation of Agriculture and Animal Husbandry (Article 48)
description: Directs the State to modernize agriculture and prohibit slaughter of cows and calves.
punishment: Implemented via agricultural and cattle protection laws.

title: Protection of Environment (Article 48A)
description: Directs the State to protect and improve the environment and safeguard forests and wildlife.

title: Protection of Monuments (Article 49)
description: Obligates the State to protect monuments and places of national importance.

title: Separation of Judiciary from Executive (Article 50)
description: Directs the State to separate the judiciary from the executive in public services.

title: Promotion of International Peace (Article 51)
description: Directs the State to promote international peace, justice, and respect for international law.

title: The President of India (Article 52)
description: There shall be a President of India as the head of the Union executive.

title: Executive Power of the Union (Article 53)
description: The executive power of the Union is vested in the President and exercised in accordance with the Constitution.

title: Election of President (Article 54)
description: The President is elected by an electoral college consisting of elected members of Parliament and State Legislative Assemblies.

title: Manner of Election of President (Article 55)
description: Provides the proportional representation system and uniformity in presidential elections.

title: Impeachment of the President (Article 61)
description: Procedure for impeachment of the President for violation of the Constitution.

title: Council of Ministers to Aid and Advise President (Article 74)
description: There shall be a Council of Ministers headed by the Prime Minister to aid and advise the President.

title: Prime Minister and Council of Ministers (Article 75)
description: Deals with appointment, tenure, and collective responsibility of the Council of Ministers.
punishment: Loss of office on loss of confidence.

title: Constitution of Parliament (Article 79)
description: Parliament consists of the President, Council of States, and House of the People.

title: Composition of the Council of States (Article 80)
description: Defines the composition and nomination of members to the Rajya Sabha.

title: Composition of the House of the People (Article 81)
description: Provides for the composition of the Lok Sabha based on population representation.

title: Chairman and Deputy Chairman of Rajya Sabha (Article 89)
description: The Vice-President is the ex-officio Chairman of the Council of States.

title: Speaker and Deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha (Article 93)
description: Provides for the election of Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People.

title: Secretariat of Parliament (Article 98)
description: Provides for a separate secretarial staff for each House of Parliament.

title: Ordinance-making Power of the President (Article 123)
description: Empowers the President to promulgate ordinances when Parliament is not in session.
punishment: Ordinance ceases if not approved by Parliament.

title: Establishment of Supreme Court (Article 124)
description: There shall be a Supreme Court of India consisting of the Chief Justice of India and other judges as Parliament may prescribe.

title: National Judicial Appointments Commission (Article 124A)
description: Provided for the establishment of NJAC for appointment of judges (declared unconstitutional).

title: Parliamentary Power on NJAC (Article 124C)
description: Allowed Parliament to regulate NJAC procedures (no longer valid).

title: Salaries of Supreme Court Judges (Article 125)
description: Judges of the Supreme Court receive salaries and allowances charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.
punishment: Cannot be reduced except during financial emergency.

title: Acting Chief Justice (Article 126)
description: President may appoint an acting Chief Justice when the office is vacant or CJI is unable to perform duties.

title: Ad Hoc Judges (Article 127)
description: Chief Justice may appoint High Court judges as ad hoc Supreme Court judges with President’s consent.

title: Retired Judges Sitting in Supreme Court (Article 128)
description: Retired Supreme Court judges may sit and act as judges with consent.

title: Supreme Court as Court of Record (Article 129)
description: Supreme Court has power to punish for contempt of itself.

title: Seat of Supreme Court (Article 130)
description: Supreme Court shall sit in Delhi or such other place as the Chief Justice may appoint.

title: Original Jurisdiction of Supreme Court (Article 131)
description: Supreme Court decides disputes between Union and States.

title: Appellate Jurisdiction in Constitutional Matters (Article 132)
description: Appeals to Supreme Court in constitutional matters from High Courts.

title: Civil Appeals to Supreme Court (Article 133)
description: Provides appellate jurisdiction in civil cases from High Courts.

title: Criminal Appeals to Supreme Court (Article 134)
description: Allows criminal appeals to Supreme Court from High Courts.

title: Certificate for Appeal to Supreme Court (Article 134A)
description: High Court may certify cases fit for appeal to Supreme Court.

title: Jurisdiction Under Existing Laws (Article 135)
description: Supreme Court has jurisdiction over matters previously under Federal Court.

title: Special Leave Petition (Article 136)
description: Supreme Court may grant special leave to appeal against any judgment.

title: Review of Supreme Court Judgments (Article 137)
description: Supreme Court has power to review its own judgments.

title: Enlargement of Supreme Court Jurisdiction (Article 138)
description: Parliament may extend Supreme Court’s jurisdiction.

title: Writ Powers Extension (Article 139)
description: Parliament may empower Supreme Court to issue writs beyond Article 32.

title: Transfer of Cases (Article 139A)
description: Supreme Court may transfer cases between High Courts.

title: Ancillary Powers of Supreme Court (Article 140)
description: Parliament may confer additional powers on Supreme Court.

title: Binding Nature of Supreme Court Judgments (Article 141)
description: Law declared by Supreme Court is binding on all courts in India.

title: Power to Do Complete Justice (Article 142)
description: Supreme Court may pass any order necessary to do complete justice.

title: Advisory Jurisdiction (Article 143)
description: President may seek Supreme Court’s opinion on questions of law.

title: Authorities to Aid Supreme Court (Article 144)
description: All authorities must act in aid of Supreme Court.

title: Rules of Supreme Court (Article 145)
description: Supreme Court may frame rules for regulating its practice and procedure.

title: Officers of Supreme Court (Article 146)
description: Appointments and service conditions of Supreme Court staff.

title: Interpretation of Judicial Articles (Article 147)
description: Defines scope of judicial references in Articles 124–147.

title: Comptroller and Auditor-General of India (Article 148)
description: There shall be a Comptroller and Auditor-General of India appointed by the President to audit accounts of the Union and States.
punishment: Removal only by impeachment like a Supreme Court judge.

title: Duties and Powers of CAG (Article 149)
description: Parliament shall prescribe the duties and powers of the Comptroller and Auditor-General.

title: Accounts of Union and States (Article 150)
description: The accounts of the Union and States shall be kept in the form prescribed by the President on advice of the CAG.

title: Audit Reports of CAG (Article 151)
description: CAG’s audit reports relating to Union and States are submitted to the President or Governor and laid before the Legislature.
punishment: Reports form basis for legislative scrutiny.

title: Definition (Article 152)
description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, the term 'State' does not include the State of Jammu and Kashmir.

title: Governors of States (Article 153)
description: There shall be a Governor for each State. One person can be appointed as Governor for two or more States.

title: Executive Power of the State (Article 154)
description: The executive power of the State shall be vested in the Governor and exercised by him directly or through officers subordinate to him.

title: Appointment of Governor (Article 155)
description: The Governor of a State shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal.

title: Term of Office of Governor (Article 156)
description: The Governor shall hold office during the pleasure of the President and normally for a term of five years.

title: Qualifications for Governor (Article 157)
description: A person must be a citizen of India and must have completed 35 years of age to be eligible for appointment as Governor.

title: Conditions of Governor’s Office (Article 158)
description: The Governor shall not be a member of Parliament or State Legislature and shall be entitled to official residence and emoluments.

title: Oath or Affirmation by Governor (Article 159)
description: Before entering office, the Governor shall take an oath or affirmation before the Chief Justice of the High Court.

title: Discharge of Governor’s Functions (Article 160)
description: The President may make arrangements for discharge of Governor’s functions in contingencies such as absence or illness.

title: Pardoning Power of Governor (Article 161)
description: The Governor has the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites or remissions of punishment for offences against state laws.

title: Extent of Executive Power of the State (Article 162)
description: The executive power of a State extends to matters on which the State Legislature has power to make laws.

title: Council of Ministers (Article 163)
description: There shall be a Council of Ministers with the Chief Minister at the head to aid and advise the Governor, except in matters where he acts in discretion.

title: Appointment and Responsibility of Ministers (Article 164)
description: The Chief Minister is appointed by the Governor; other ministers are appointed on the advice of the Chief Minister and are collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly.
punishment: Loss of office on loss of confidence.

title: Advocate-General for the State (Article 165)
description: The Governor shall appoint an Advocate-General who is qualified to be a High Court judge to advise the State Government on legal matters.

title: Conduct of Business of State Government (Article 166)
description: All executive actions of the State Government shall be expressed in the name of the Governor and conducted as per rules framed by him.

title: Duties of the Chief Minister (Article 167)
description: The Chief Minister shall communicate decisions of the Council of Ministers to the Governor and furnish information relating to State administration.

title: Constitution of State Legislatures (Article 168)
description: Every State shall have a Legislature consisting of the Governor and one or two Houses depending on the State.

title: Constitution of State Legislatures (Article 168)
description: Every State shall have a Legislature consisting of the Governor and one or two Houses depending on the State.

title: Composition of Legislative Assembly (Article 170)
description: The Legislative Assembly consists of members chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the State.

title: Composition of Legislative Council (Article 171)
description: The Legislative Council consists of members elected and nominated from various categories such as local bodies, graduates, teachers, and Governor nominees.

title: Duration of State Legislature (Article 172)
description: The Legislative Assembly shall continue for five years unless sooner dissolved; Legislative Council is permanent.

title: Qualifications for State Legislature Membership (Article 173)
description: A person must be a citizen of India and meet age and other qualifications prescribed by law to be a member of State Legislature.

title: Sessions of State Legislature (Article 174)
description: The Governor shall summon, prorogue the State Legislature and may dissolve the Legislative Assembly.

title: Governor’s Address and Messages (Article 175)
description: The Governor may address the State Legislature and send messages regarding bills or other matters.

title: Special Address by Governor (Article 176)
description: The Governor shall address the Legislative Assembly at the commencement of the first session after elections and each year.

title: Rights of Ministers and Advocate-General (Article 177)
description: Ministers and Advocate-General have the right to speak and take part in proceedings of the State Legislature.

title: Speaker and Deputy Speaker (Article 178)
description: Every Legislative Assembly shall choose a Speaker and a Deputy Speaker from among its members.

title: Vacation and Resignation of Office (Article 179)
description: The Speaker or Deputy Speaker may resign, be removed by resolution, or vacate office on ceasing to be a member.

title: Performance of Duties of Speaker (Article 180)
description: Deputy Speaker or a member appointed by the Governor performs duties when the Speaker’s office is vacant.

title: Restriction During Removal Proceedings (Article 181)
description: The Speaker or Deputy Speaker shall not preside while a resolution for removal is under consideration.

title: Chairman and Deputy Chairman (Article 182)
description: The Legislative Council shall choose a Chairman and a Deputy Chairman from among its members.

title: Vacation and Resignation of Office (Article 183)
description: The Chairman or Deputy Chairman may resign, be removed, or vacate office upon ceasing to be a member.

title: Performance of Duties of Chairman (Article 184)
description: Deputy Chairman or a member appointed by the Governor performs duties when the Chairman’s office is vacant.

title: Restriction During Removal Proceedings (Article 185)
description: The Chairman or Deputy Chairman shall not preside while a resolution for removal is under consideration.

title: Salaries and Allowances of Presiding Officers (Article 186)
description: Salaries and allowances of presiding officers are charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State.

title: Secretariat of State Legislature (Article 187)
description: Each House of the State Legislature shall have a separate secretarial staff regulated by law.

title: Oath or Affirmation by Members (Article 188)
description: Every member of the State Legislature shall take an oath or affirmation before taking their seat.
punishment: Cannot sit or vote without oath.

title: Voting in the Legislature (Article 189)
description: All questions in a House shall be determined by a majority of members present and voting; presiding officer has casting vote.

title: Vacation of Seats (Article 190)
description: A member shall vacate his seat if disqualified, resigns, or is absent without permission for 60 days.

title: Disqualifications for Membership (Article 191)
description: A person is disqualified if holding office of profit, unsound mind, insolvent, or disqualified by law.

title: Decision on Disqualification (Article 192)
description: The Governor decides questions of disqualification after consulting the Election Commission.

title: Penalty for Unauthorized Sitting or Voting (Article 193)
description: A person sitting or voting without taking oath or when disqualified shall be liable to a fine.

title: Legislative Privileges (Article 194)
description: State Legislature members enjoy freedom of speech and other privileges similar to Parliament.
punishment: Protection from legal action for legislative speech.

title: Salaries and Allowances of Members (Article 195)
description: Members of State Legislature are entitled to salaries and allowances as determined by law.

title: Introduction and Passing of Bills (Article 196)
description: A Bill may originate in either House except Money Bills which originate only in Legislative Assembly.

title: Restriction on Legislative Council (Article 197)
description: Legislative Council can delay but not reject Money Bills passed by Legislative Assembly.

title: Special Procedure for Money Bills (Article 198)
description: Money Bills passed by the Legislative Assembly are transmitted to the Legislative Council, which must return them within the prescribed time.

title: Money Bills Defined (Article 199)
description: A Bill is a Money Bill if it contains provisions related to taxation, borrowing, expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of the State.

title: Assent to Bills by Governor (Article 200)
description: When a Bill is presented, the Governor may give assent, withhold assent, return it, or reserve it for President’s consideration.

title: President’s Assent to Reserved Bills (Article 201)
description: When a Bill is reserved, the President may assent or withhold assent or return it to the State Legislature.

title: Annual Financial Statement (Article 202)
description: The Governor shall lay before the State Legislature the Annual Financial Statement (State Budget).

title: Procedure for Estimates (Article 203)
description: Estimates of expenditure must be voted by the Legislative Assembly and cannot be voted upon by the Legislative Council.

title: Appropriation Bills (Article 204)
description: No money shall be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund except under an Appropriation Act.

title: Supplementary and Excess Grants (Article 205)
description: Provision for additional or excess expenditure not included in the Annual Financial Statement.

title: Votes on Account and Credit (Article 206)
description: The Legislative Assembly may grant votes on account for urgent expenditure.

title: Special Provisions for Financial Bills (Article 207)
description: Financial Bills require the Governor’s recommendation before introduction.

title: Rules of Procedure (Article 208)
description: Each House of the State Legislature may make rules for regulating its procedure and conduct of business.

title: Procedure Regulation by Law (Article 209)
description: The Legislature may regulate its procedure by law until rules are framed.

title: Language of State Legislature (Article 210)
description: Business in the Legislature shall be conducted in the official language or Hindi or English as authorized.

title: Restriction on Discussion (Article 211)
description: No discussion shall take place in the Legislature regarding the conduct of judges of Supreme Court or High Court.

title: Courts and Legislative Proceedings (Article 212)
description: Courts shall not inquire into proceedings of the State Legislature for procedural irregularities.

title: Ordinance-making Power of the Governor (Article 213)
description: When the State Legislature is not in session and circumstances require immediate action, the Governor may promulgate Ordinances having the same force as an Act of the Legislature.
punishment: Ordinance ceases to operate six weeks after reassembly unless approved.

title: High Courts for States (Article 214)
description: There shall be a High Court for each State of India.

title: High Court as Court of Record (Article 215)
description: Every High Court shall be a court of record and shall have power to punish for contempt of itself.

title: Constitution of High Courts (Article 216)
description: Every High Court shall consist of a Chief Justice and such other Judges as the President may appoint.

title: Appointment and Conditions of High Court Judges (Article 217)
description: Judges of High Courts are appointed by the President after consultation and hold office till age of 62 years.

title: Application of SC Judge Provisions to HC Judges (Article 218)
description: Provisions relating to removal, salaries, and privileges of Supreme Court judges apply to High Court judges.
punishment: Same removal procedure as SC judges.

title: Oath or Affirmation by High Court Judges (Article 219)
description: Every Judge of a High Court shall take an oath before the Governor of the State.

title: Restriction on Practice (Article 220)
description: A retired High Court judge shall not plead or act in any court except the Supreme Court and other High Courts.

title: Salaries and Allowances of High Court Judges (Article 221)
description: Judges of High Courts shall receive salaries and pensions as determined by Parliament and charged on Consolidated Fund.

title: Transfer of High Court Judges (Article 222)
description: The President may transfer a Judge from one High Court to another after consultation with the Chief Justice of India.

title: Acting Chief Justice (Article 223)
description: When the office of Chief Justice is vacant, the President appoints an Acting Chief Justice.

title: Additional and Acting Judges (Article 224)
description: The President may appoint Additional or Acting Judges for temporary increase in workload or vacancy.

title: Additional and Acting Judges (Article 224)
description: The President may appoint Additional or Acting Judges for temporary increase in workload or vacancy.

title: Appointment of Retired Judges (Article 224A)
description: The Chief Justice of a High Court may request retired judges to sit and act as judges.

title: Jurisdiction of High Courts (Article 225)
description: Jurisdiction of existing High Courts remains as before unless altered by law.

title: Writ Jurisdiction of High Courts (Article 226)
description: High Courts may issue writs for enforcement of Fundamental Rights and for any other purpose.

title: Superintendence of High Courts (Article 227)
description: Every High Court has superintendence over all courts and tribunals within its jurisdiction.

title: Transfer of Cases to High Court (Article 228)
description: The High Court may withdraw a case involving substantial constitutional questions from a subordinate court.

title: Officers and Servants of High Courts (Article 229)
description: Appointments and service conditions of High Court staff are controlled by the Chief Justice of the High Court.

title: Extension of High Court Jurisdiction (Article 230)
description: Parliament may extend the jurisdiction of a High Court to Union Territories.

title: Common High Court for Two or More States (Article 231)
description: Parliament may establish a common High Court for two or more States or Union Territories.

title: Appointment of District Judges (Article 233)
description: Appointments, postings, and promotions of district judges are made by the Governor in consultation with the High Court.
punishment: Invalid appointments can be challenged constitutionally.

title: Validation of District Judge Appointments (Article 233A)
description: Validates appointments of district judges made before the commencement of the Constitution (Twentieth Amendment) Act, 1966.

title: Recruitment of Judicial Officers (Article 234)
description: Appointments of persons other than district judges to the judicial service are made by the Governor in consultation with the High Court and Public Service Commission.

title: Control of High Court Over Subordinate Courts (Article 235)
description: The High Court has control over district courts and courts subordinate thereto, including disciplinary matters.

title: Interpretation of Subordinate Courts Provisions (Article 236)
description: Defines terms such as 'district judge' and 'judicial service' for this Chapter.

title: Application of Provisions to Magistrates (Article 237)
description: The Governor may apply provisions of this Chapter to magistrates as deemed appropriate.

title: Part B States (Article 238) – Repealed
description: This Article relating to Part B States was repealed by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

title: Administration of Union Territories (Article 239)
description: Union Territories are administered by the President through an Administrator appointed by him.

title: Legislature or Council of Ministers for Certain Union Territories (Article 239A)
description: Parliament may create legislatures or councils of ministers for certain Union Territories.

title: Special Status of Delhi (Article 239AA)
description: Provides for a Legislative Assembly and Council of Ministers for the National Capital Territory of Delhi.

title: President’s Rule in Union Territories (Article 239AB)
description: Allows the President to suspend operation of Article 239AA in case of constitutional failure in Delhi.

title: Ordinance Powers in Union Territories (Article 239B)
description: Administrator may promulgate ordinances when the legislature is not in session.

title: President’s Regulation-making Power (Article 240)
description: President may make regulations for peace, progress, and good governance of certain Union Territories.

title: High Courts for Union Territories (Article 241)
description: Parliament may establish High Courts or extend jurisdiction of High Courts to Union Territories.

title: Coorg (Article 242) – Repealed
description: This Article relating to the State of Coorg was repealed by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

title: Definitions (Article 243)
description: Defines key terms such as Panchayat, Gram Sabha, village, district, and population for Part IX.

title: Gram Sabha (Article 243A)
description: Gram Sabha consists of all registered voters in a village and exercises powers as provided by State law.

title: Constitution of Panchayats (Article 243B)
description: Provides for Panchayats at village, intermediate, and district levels in every State.

title: Composition of Panchayats (Article 243C)
description: Members of Panchayats are elected directly; Chairpersons elected as per State law.

title: Reservation in Panchayats (Article 243D)
description: Reserves seats for SCs, STs, and women (not less than one-third) in Panchayats.

title: Duration of Panchayats (Article 243E)
description: Every Panchayat shall continue for five years unless dissolved earlier.

title: Disqualification of Members (Article 243F)
description: Provides grounds for disqualification of Panchayat members under State law.

title: Powers of Panchayats (Article 243G)
description: States may endow Panchayats with powers to function as institutions of self-government.

title: Financial Powers of Panchayats (Article 243H)
description: Panchayats may levy, collect, and appropriate taxes, duties, tolls, and fees.

title: State Finance Commission (Article 243I)
description: Governor constitutes a Finance Commission every five years to review Panchayat finances.

title: Audit of Panchayat Accounts (Article 243J)
description: State Legislature may provide for audit of Panchayat accounts.

title: Panchayat Elections (Article 243K)
description: Elections are conducted under the supervision of the State Election Commission.

title: Application to Union Territories (Article 243L)
description: Provisions of Part IX apply to Union Territories with modifications.

title: Exemptions from Part IX (Article 243M)
description: Certain areas like Scheduled Areas and tribal regions are exempted.

title: Continuance of Existing Laws (Article 243N)
description: Existing Panchayat laws continue until amended or repealed.

title: Bar on Court Interference (Article 243O)
description: Courts cannot interfere in Panchayat electoral matters except through election petitions.

title: Definitions (Article 243P)
description: Defines terms such as Municipality, Municipal area, Nagar Panchayat, Municipal Council, and Municipal Corporation.

title: Constitution of Municipalities (Article 243Q)
description: Municipalities are constituted in urban areas based on population and development level.

title: Composition of Municipalities (Article 243R)
description: Members are directly elected; State Legislature may include nominated members without voting rights.

title: Wards Committees (Article 243S)
description: Wards Committees are constituted in municipalities with population above a specified limit.

title: Reservation in Municipalities (Article 243T)
description: Provides reservation for SCs, STs, and women (not less than one-third) in Municipal bodies.

title: Duration of Municipalities (Article 243U)
description: Municipalities have a term of five years unless dissolved earlier.

title: Disqualification of Members (Article 243V)
description: Grounds for disqualification of municipal members are prescribed by State law.

title: Powers of Municipalities (Article 243W)
description: States may endow Municipalities with powers to function as institutions of self-government.

title: Financial Powers of Municipalities (Article 243X)
description: Municipalities may levy and collect taxes, duties, tolls, and fees.

title: Finance Commission for Municipalities (Article 243Y)
description: State Finance Commission reviews financial position of Municipalities every five years.

title: Audit of Municipal Accounts (Article 243Z)
description: State Legislature may provide for audit of Municipal accounts.

title: Municipal Elections (Article 243ZA)
description: Municipal elections are conducted by the State Election Commission.

title: Application to Union Territories (Article 243ZB)
description: Provisions of Part IXA apply to Union Territories with modifications.

title: Exemptions from Part IXA (Article 243ZC)
description: Certain areas like Scheduled Areas and tribal regions are exempted.

title: District Planning Committee (Article 243ZD)
description: District Planning Committees consolidate plans prepared by Panchayats and Municipalities.

title: Metropolitan Planning Committee (Article 243ZE)
description: Metropolitan Planning Committees prepare development plans for metropolitan areas.

title: Continuance of Existing Laws (Article 243ZF)
description: Existing municipal laws continue until amended or repealed.

title: Bar on Court Interference (Article 243ZG)
description: Courts cannot interfere in municipal election matters except through election petitions.

title: Definitions (Article 243ZH)
description: Defines terms such as co-operative society, board, office bearer, and member for Part IXB.

title: Incorporation of Co-operative Societies (Article 243ZI)
description: State Legislature may make laws for incorporation, regulation, and winding up of co-operative societies.

title: Board Members and Tenure (Article 243ZJ)
description: Fixes maximum number of directors and a five-year term for the board of co-operative societies.

title: Election of Co-operative Board (Article 243ZK)
description: Elections to the board shall be conducted before expiry of the term.

title: Supersession of Co-operative Board (Article 243ZL)
description: Board may be superseded for a limited period under specified conditions.

title: Audit of Co-operative Societies (Article 243ZM)
description: Accounts of co-operative societies shall be audited by qualified auditors.

title: General Body Meetings (Article 243ZN)
description: Annual General Body Meeting must be convened within a prescribed period.

title: Right to Information (Article 243ZO)
description: Members have access to information relating to the functioning of co-operative societies.

title: Submission of Returns (Article 243ZP)
description: Co-operative societies must submit annual returns to authorities.

title: Offences in Co-operative Societies (Article 243ZQ)
description: State law may specify offences and penalties for co-operative societies.

title: Multi-State Co-operative Societies (Article 243ZR)
description: Provisions apply to multi-state co-operative societies subject to Central law.

title: Application to Union Territories (Article 243ZS)
description: Provisions of Part IXB apply to Union Territories with modifications.

title: Continuance of Existing Laws (Article 243ZT)
description: Existing co-operative laws continue until amended or repealed.

title: Administration of Scheduled and Tribal Areas (Article 244)
description: Provides that Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas shall be administered in accordance with the Fifth and Sixth Schedules of the Constitution.

title: Autonomous State in Assam (Article 244A)
description: Parliament may form an autonomous State within Assam comprising certain tribal areas and provide for a legislature or council of ministers.

title: Extent of Laws (Article 245)
description: Parliament may make laws for the whole or any part of India; State Legislatures may make laws for their respective States.

title: Distribution of Legislative Powers (Article 246)
description: Divides legislative subjects into Union List, State List, and Concurrent List under the Seventh Schedule.

title: Special Provision for Goods and Services Tax (Article 246A)
description: Parliament and State Legislatures have concurrent powers to make laws regarding GST.

title: Power to Establish Additional Courts (Article 247)
description: Parliament may establish courts for better administration of laws made by it.

title: Residuary Powers (Article 248)
description: Parliament has exclusive power to legislate on matters not enumerated in any list.

title: Parliament’s Power in National Interest (Article 249)
description: Parliament may legislate on State List matters if Rajya Sabha passes a resolution in national interest.

title: Parliament’s Power During Emergency (Article 250)
description: Parliament may legislate on State List matters during a national emergency.

title: Union Law Prevails in Case of Conflict (Article 251)
description: Union law prevails over State law on matters under Articles 249 and 250.

title: Parliament’s Power with State Consent (Article 252)
description: Parliament may legislate for two or more States with their consent on State List matters.

title: Legislation for International Treaties (Article 253)
description: Parliament may make laws to implement international treaties and agreements.

title: Repugnancy Between Union and State Laws (Article 254)
description: Union law prevails over State law in case of inconsistency in Concurrent List matters.
punishment: Union law supremacy unless President assents.

title: Procedural Requirements for Certain Bills (Article 255)
description: Failure to comply with recommendation requirements does not invalidate an Act.

title: Obligation of States and Union (Article 256)
description: States must ensure compliance with laws made by Parliament; the Union may give directions to States.

title: Union Control over States (Article 257)
description: Union may give directions to States regarding national importance and communication infrastructure.

title: Delegation of Union Functions (Article 258)
description: Union may entrust its executive functions to States with consent.

title: Delegation of State Functions to Union (Article 258A)
description: States may entrust their executive functions to the Union.

title: Armed Forces in Aid of Civil Power (Article 259) – Repealed
description: This Article relating to armed forces assistance was repealed by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

title: Jurisdiction Outside India (Article 260)
description: Union may exercise jurisdiction outside India as per agreements with foreign countries.

title: Public Acts and Judicial Proceedings (Article 261)
description: Full faith and credit shall be given to public acts, records, and judicial proceedings throughout India.

title: Water Dispute Adjudication (Article 262)
description: Parliament may provide for adjudication of inter-State river water disputes.

title: Inter-State Council (Article 263)
description: President may establish an Inter-State Council for coordination between States and the Union.

title: Interpretation (Article 264)
description: Defines terms used in Part XII relating to finance.

title: Interpretation (Article 264)
description: Defines terms used in Part XII relating to finance.

title: Levy and Collection of Taxes (Article 265)
description: No tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law.

title: Consolidated Fund and Public Account (Article 266)
description: Establishes Consolidated Fund and Public Account of India and States.

title: Contingency Fund (Article 267)
description: Provides for Contingency Funds for India and States to meet unforeseen expenditure.

title: Stamp Duties (Article 268)
description: Stamp duties are levied by the Union but collected and appropriated by the States.

title: Assigned Taxes (Article 269)
description: Certain taxes are levied and collected by the Union but assigned to States.

title: IGST Provision (Article 269A)
description: GST on inter-State supplies is levied and collected by the Union and apportioned between Union and States.

title: Distribution of Taxes (Article 270)
description: Taxes collected by the Union are distributed between Union and States.

title: Surcharge on Taxes (Article 271)
description: Parliament may levy surcharge on certain taxes for Union purposes.

title: Distribution of Taxes (Article 272) – Repealed
description: This Article was repealed by the Constitution (Eighty-eighth Amendment) Act, 2003.

title: Grants in Lieu of Export Duties (Article 273)
description: Provides for grants to States in lieu of export duties on jute and jute products.

title: Recommendation for Financial Bills (Article 274)
description: Certain financial bills affecting State taxation require prior Presidential recommendation.

title: Grants from Union to States (Article 275)
description: Union may make grants to States in need of assistance.

title: Income Tax (Article 276)
description: Provides for the levy of income tax by the Union and its collection and appropriation between Union and States.

title: Savings of Existing Taxes (Article 277)
description: Existing taxes at the commencement of the Constitution continue until Parliament provides otherwise.

title: Agreements with States (Article 278) – Repealed
description: This Article was repealed by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

title: Net Proceeds of Taxes (Article 279)
description: Defines how net proceeds of taxes are calculated for distribution.

title: GST Council (Article 279A)
description: Establishes the GST Council to make recommendations on GST matters.

title: Finance Commission (Article 280)
description: President constitutes a Finance Commission every five years to recommend revenue distribution.

title: Finance Commission Reports (Article 281)
description: Recommendations of the Finance Commission are laid before Parliament.

title: Finance Commission Reports (Article 281)
description: Recommendations of the Finance Commission are laid before Parliament.

title: Public Expenditure (Article 282)
description: Union or State may make grants for any public purpose.

title: Custody of Funds (Article 283)
description: Provides for custody and operation of Consolidated and Public Account funds.

title: Suitors’ Deposits (Article 284)
description: Deals with custody of deposits made in courts.

title: Exemption from Taxation (Article 285)
description: Union property is exempt from State taxation unless Parliament provides otherwise.

title: Restrictions on State Taxation (Article 286)
description: States cannot tax inter-State or international trade sales.

title: Electricity Tax Exemption (Article 287)
description: Union property is exempt from State electricity tax.

title: Electricity Tax Exemption (Article 287)
description: Union property is exempt from State electricity tax.

title: Water and Electricity Tax Exemption (Article 288)
description: State taxation on water or electricity used by Union requires Presidential consent.

title: State Property Tax Exemption (Article 289)
description: State property is exempt from Union taxation except for commercial activities.

title: Adjustment of Expenses (Article 290)
description: Provides for adjustment of certain expenses between Union and States.

title: Devaswom Fund Grants (Article 290A)
description: Provides grants to Devaswom Funds in Kerala and Tamil Nadu.

title: Privy Purse (Article 291) – Repealed
description: This Article relating to privy purses was repealed by the Constitution (Twenty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1971.

title: Borrowing by the Union (Article 292)
description: The Government of India may borrow money upon the security of the Consolidated Fund of India within limits fixed by Parliament.

title: Borrowing by States (Article 293)
description: States may borrow within India subject to limits imposed by their legislatures and with Union consent if indebted to the Union.

title: Succession to Property and Liabilities (Article 294)
description: Property, assets, rights, liabilities, and obligations of the Government of India and States succeed as per constitutional allocation.

title: Succession in Special Cases (Article 295)
description: Provides succession of property and liabilities relating to Indian States integrated into India.

title: Escheat or Lapse (Article 296)
description: Property without a legal owner shall vest in the Union or the State as per jurisdiction.

title: Territorial Waters and Resources (Article 297)
description: All lands, minerals, and resources under ocean waters vest in the Union of India.

title: Trade and Business Powers (Article 298)
description: Union and States may carry on trade, business, and make contracts for any purpose.

title: Government Contracts (Article 299)
description: Contracts made in the exercise of executive power must be expressed in the name of the President or Governor.
punishment: Invalid if constitutional procedure not followed.

title: Suits by or Against Government (Article 300)
description: The Government of India and States may sue or be sued as per law.

title: Right to Property (Article 300A)
description: No person shall be deprived of property except by authority of law.

title: Freedom of Trade, Commerce and Intercourse
description: Trade, commerce and intercourse throughout the territory of India shall be free.

title: Power of Parliament to Impose Restrictions
description: Parliament may impose reasonable restrictions on the freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse in the public interest.

title: Restriction on Discriminatory Legislation
description: Neither Parliament nor State Legislatures shall make laws giving preference to one State over another, except to deal with scarcity of goods.

title: Restrictions on Trade by States
description: States may impose non-discriminatory taxes on goods from other States and reasonable restrictions in public interest with prior Presidential sanction.

title: Saving of Existing Laws
description: Existing laws relating to trade, commerce and intercourse are protected even if inconsistent with Article 301.

title: Special Provisions (Omitted)
description: This article provided special provisions for certain States and has been repealed.

title: Appointment of Authority for Trade Regulation
description: Parliament may appoint an authority to carry out the purposes of Articles 301 to 304.
This Part applies to persons appointed to public services and posts in connection with the affairs of the Union or of any State.
Parliament or State Legislature may regulate the recruitment and conditions of service of persons serving the Union or a State.
Every person serving the Union or a State holds office during the pleasure of the President or the Governor respectively.
No civil servant shall be dismissed, removed, or reduced in rank without an inquiry and reasonable opportunity of being heard.
Parliament may create All-India Services common to the Union and the States if the Rajya Sabha passes a resolution.
Parliament may vary or revoke conditions of service of officers of All-India Services.
Existing laws relating to public services shall continue in force until altered or repealed.
This article relating to protection of certain public servants has been repealed.
There shall be a Public Service Commission for the Union and for each State.
Appointment and tenure of members of the Public Service Commission shall be governed by constitutional provisions.
Members of a Public Service Commission may be removed only on specific grounds and by prescribed procedure.
The President or Governor may make regulations regarding conditions of service of PSC members.
Restrictions are placed on future employment of members after leaving the Public Service Commission.
Public Service Commissions shall be consulted on matters of recruitment and service conditions.
Parliament or State Legislature may extend the functions of Public Service Commissions.
Expenses of the Public Service Commission shall be charged on the Consolidated Fund.
Public Service Commissions shall present annual reports to the President or the Governor.
Parliament may provide for the establishment of Administrative Tribunals for adjudication of disputes related to recruitment and conditions of service of public servants.
Parliament and State Legislatures may provide for the establishment of tribunals for matters such as taxation, industrial disputes, land reforms, and elections.
The superintendence, direction and control of elections to Parliament, State Legislatures, and the offices of President and Vice-President shall be vested in the Election Commission.
No person shall be ineligible for inclusion in an electoral roll on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, or any of them.
Elections to the House of the People and State Legislative Assemblies shall be based on adult suffrage.
Parliament may make laws relating to all matters connected with elections to Parliament and State Legislatures.
State Legislatures may make laws relating to elections to the Legislature of the State, subject to parliamentary law.
Courts shall not interfere in electoral matters except through election petitions as provided by law.
This article relating to special provisions as to elections to Parliament has been repealed.
Seats shall be reserved in the House of the People for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.
The President may nominate members of the Anglo-Indian community to the House of the People if they are not adequately represented.
Seats shall be reserved for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in the Legislative Assemblies of the States.
The Governor may nominate members of the Anglo-Indian community to the Legislative Assembly of a State if they are not adequately represented.
Provisions for reservation of seats and special representation shall cease after a specified period unless extended.
Claims of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes shall be taken into consideration consistently with the maintenance of efficiency of administration.
Special provisions shall be made for the Anglo-Indian community in certain services during a transitional period.
Special provisions shall be made for the educational grants of the Anglo-Indian community.
There shall be a National Commission for the Scheduled Castes to investigate and monitor safeguards provided for them.
There shall be a National Commission for the Scheduled Tribes to investigate and monitor safeguards provided for them.
There shall be a National Commission for Backward Classes to investigate and monitor safeguards provided for them.
The President may appoint a Commission to report on the administration of Scheduled Areas and the welfare of Scheduled Tribes.
The President may appoint a Commission to investigate the conditions of socially and educationally backward classes.
The President may specify the Scheduled Castes for a State or Union Territory.
The President may specify the Scheduled Tribes for a State or Union Territory.
Hindi in Devanagari script shall be the official language of the Union, and English shall continue for official purposes as provided by law.
A Commission and a Committee of Parliament shall be constituted to review the progressive use of Hindi for official purposes.
The Legislature of a State may adopt any one or more languages in use in the State or Hindi as the official language of the State.
The language for communication between States and between a State and the Union shall be as prescribed by law.
The President may recognize a language spoken by a section of the population of a State for official purposes.
Proceedings in the Supreme Court and High Courts and authoritative texts of laws shall be in English unless Parliament provides otherwise.
Special procedure shall be followed for enacting laws related to language before the expiry of a specified period.
Every person shall be entitled to submit a representation for the redress of grievances in any language used in the Union or State.
Every State and local authority shall provide facilities for instruction in the mother tongue at the primary stage of education to linguistic minority groups.
There shall be a Special Officer for linguistic minorities to investigate and report on safeguards provided to them.
The Union shall promote the spread of Hindi and develop it as a medium of expression for all elements of the composite culture of India.
The President may proclaim a National Emergency if satisfied that the security of India or any part thereof is threatened by war, external aggression, or armed rebellion.
During a National Emergency, the executive and legislative powers of the Union shall extend to the States as provided by the Constitution.
Provisions relating to distribution of revenues between the Union and the States may be modified during an Emergency.
It shall be the duty of the Union to protect every State against external aggression and internal disturbance.
If the constitutional machinery of a State fails, the President may assume the functions of the State Government.
Parliament may confer powers on the President to make laws for a State under President’s Rule.
Fundamental Rights under Article 19 shall be suspended during a National Emergency.
The President may suspend the enforcement of certain Fundamental Rights during an Emergency.
The President may proclaim a Financial Emergency if the financial stability of India is threatened.
The President and the Governors shall not be answerable to any court for the exercise of the powers and duties of their office.

title: Establishment of Supreme Court (Article 124)
description: There shall be a Supreme Court of India consisting of the Chief Justice of India and other judges as Parliament may prescribe.

title: National Judicial Appointments Commission (Article 124A)
description: Provided for the establishment of NJAC for appointment of judges (declared unconstitutional).

title: Parliamentary Power on NJAC (Article 124C)
description: Allowed Parliament to regulate NJAC procedures (no longer valid).

title: Salaries of Supreme Court Judges (Article 125)
description: Judges of the Supreme Court receive salaries and allowances charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.
punishment: Cannot be reduced except during financial emergency.

title: Acting Chief Justice (Article 126)
description: President may appoint an acting Chief Justice when the office is vacant or CJI is unable to perform duties.

title: Ad Hoc Judges (Article 127)
description: Chief Justice may appoint High Court judges as ad hoc Supreme Court judges with President’s consent.

title: Retired Judges Sitting in Supreme Court (Article 128)
description: Retired Supreme Court judges may sit and act as judges with consent.

title: Supreme Court as Court of Record (Article 129)
description: Supreme Court has power to punish for contempt of itself.

title: Seat of Supreme Court (Article 130)
description: Supreme Court shall sit in Delhi or such other place as the Chief Justice may appoint.

title: Original Jurisdiction of Supreme Court (Article 131)
description: Supreme Court decides disputes between Union and States.

title: Appellate Jurisdiction in Constitutional Matters (Article 132)
description: Appeals to Supreme Court in constitutional matters from High Courts.

title: Civil Appeals to Supreme Court (Article 133)
description: Provides appellate jurisdiction in civil cases from High Courts.

title: Criminal Appeals to Supreme Court (Article 134)
description: Allows criminal appeals to Supreme Court from High Courts.

title: Certificate for Appeal to Supreme Court (Article 134A)
description: High Court may certify cases fit for appeal to Supreme Court.

title: Jurisdiction Under Existing Laws (Article 135)
description: Supreme Court has jurisdiction over matters previously under Federal Court.

title: Special Leave Petition (Article 136)
description: Supreme Court may grant special leave to appeal against any judgment.

title: Review of Supreme Court Judgments (Article 137)
description: Supreme Court has power to review its own judgments.

title: Enlargement of Supreme Court Jurisdiction (Article 138)
description: Parliament may extend Supreme Court’s jurisdiction.

title: Writ Powers Extension (Article 139)
description: Parliament may empower Supreme Court to issue writs beyond Article 32.

title: Transfer of Cases (Article 139A)
description: Supreme Court may transfer cases between High Courts.

title: Ancillary Powers of Supreme Court (Article 140)
description: Parliament may confer additional powers on Supreme Court.

title: Binding Nature of Supreme Court Judgments (Article 141)
description: Law declared by Supreme Court is binding on all courts in India.

title: Power to Do Complete Justice (Article 142)
description: Supreme Court may pass any order necessary to do complete justice.

title: Advisory Jurisdiction (Article 143)
description: President may seek Supreme Court’s opinion on questions of law.

title: Authorities to Aid Supreme Court (Article 144)
description: All authorities must act in aid of Supreme Court.

title: Rules of Supreme Court (Article 145)
description: Supreme Court may frame rules for regulating its practice and procedure.

title: Officers of Supreme Court (Article 146)
description: Appointments and service conditions of Supreme Court staff.

title: Interpretation of Judicial Articles (Article 147)
description: Defines scope of judicial references in Articles 124–147.

title: Comptroller and Auditor-General of India (Article 148)
description: There shall be a Comptroller and Auditor-General of India appointed by the President to audit accounts of the Union and States.
punishment: Removal only by impeachment like a Supreme Court judge.

title: Duties and Powers of CAG (Article 149)
description: Parliament shall prescribe the duties and powers of the Comptroller and Auditor-General.

title: Accounts of Union and States (Article 150)
description: The accounts of the Union and States shall be kept in the form prescribed by the President on advice of the CAG.

title: Audit Reports of CAG (Article 151)
description: CAG’s audit reports relating to Union and States are submitted to the President or Governor and laid before the Legislature.
punishment: Reports form basis for legislative scrutiny.

title: Definition (Article 152)
description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, the term 'State' does not include the State of Jammu and Kashmir.

title: Governors of States (Article 153)
description: There shall be a Governor for each State. One person can be appointed as Governor for two or more States.

title: Executive Power of the State (Article 154)
description: The executive power of the State shall be vested in the Governor and exercised by him directly or through officers subordinate to him.

title: Appointment of Governor (Article 155)
description: The Governor of a State shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal.

title: Term of Office of Governor (Article 156)
description: The Governor shall hold office during the pleasure of the President and normally for a term of five years.

title: Qualifications for Governor (Article 157)
description: A person must be a citizen of India and must have completed 35 years of age to be eligible for appointment as Governor.

title: Conditions of Governor’s Office (Article 158)
description: The Governor shall not be a member of Parliament or State Legislature and shall be entitled to official residence and emoluments.

title: Oath or Affirmation by Governor (Article 159)
description: Before entering office, the Governor shall take an oath or affirmation before the Chief Justice of the High Court.

title: Discharge of Governor’s Functions (Article 160)
description: The President may make arrangements for discharge of Governor’s functions in contingencies such as absence or illness.

title: Pardoning Power of Governor (Article 161)
description: The Governor has the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites or remissions of punishment for offences against state laws.

title: Extent of Executive Power of the State (Article 162)
description: The executive power of a State extends to matters on which the State Legislature has power to make laws.

title: Council of Ministers (Article 163)
description: There shall be a Council of Ministers with the Chief Minister at the head to aid and advise the Governor, except in matters where he acts in discretion.

title: Appointment and Responsibility of Ministers (Article 164)
description: The Chief Minister is appointed by the Governor; other ministers are appointed on the advice of the Chief Minister and are collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly.
punishment: Loss of office on loss of confidence.

title: Advocate-General for the State (Article 165)
description: The Governor shall appoint an Advocate-General who is qualified to be a High Court judge to advise the State Government on legal matters.

title: Conduct of Business of State Government (Article 166)
description: All executive actions of the State Government shall be expressed in the name of the Governor and conducted as per rules framed by him.

title: Duties of the Chief Minister (Article 167)
description: The Chief Minister shall communicate decisions of the Council of Ministers to the Governor and furnish information relating to State administration.

title: Constitution of State Legislatures (Article 168)
description: Every State shall have a Legislature consisting of the Governor and one or two Houses depending on the State.

title: Constitution of State Legislatures (Article 168)
description: Every State shall have a Legislature consisting of the Governor and one or two Houses depending on the State.

title: Composition of Legislative Assembly (Article 170)
description: The Legislative Assembly consists of members chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the State.

title: Composition of Legislative Council (Article 171)
description: The Legislative Council consists of members elected and nominated from various categories such as local bodies, graduates, teachers, and Governor nominees.

title: Duration of State Legislature (Article 172)
description: The Legislative Assembly shall continue for five years unless sooner dissolved; Legislative Council is permanent.

title: Qualifications for State Legislature Membership (Article 173)
description: A person must be a citizen of India and meet age and other qualifications prescribed by law to be a member of State Legislature.

title: Sessions of State Legislature (Article 174)
description: The Governor shall summon, prorogue the State Legislature and may dissolve the Legislative Assembly.

title: Governor’s Address and Messages (Article 175)
description: The Governor may address the State Legislature and send messages regarding bills or other matters.

title: Special Address by Governor (Article 176)
description: The Governor shall address the Legislative Assembly at the commencement of the first session after elections and each year.

title: Rights of Ministers and Advocate-General (Article 177)
description: Ministers and Advocate-General have the right to speak and take part in proceedings of the State Legislature.

title: Speaker and Deputy Speaker (Article 178)
description: Every Legislative Assembly shall choose a Speaker and a Deputy Speaker from among its members.

title: Vacation and Resignation of Office (Article 179)
description: The Speaker or Deputy Speaker may resign, be removed by resolution, or vacate office on ceasing to be a member.

title: Performance of Duties of Speaker (Article 180)
description: Deputy Speaker or a member appointed by the Governor performs duties when the Speaker’s office is vacant.

title: Restriction During Removal Proceedings (Article 181)
description: The Speaker or Deputy Speaker shall not preside while a resolution for removal is under consideration.

title: Chairman and Deputy Chairman (Article 182)
description: The Legislative Council shall choose a Chairman and a Deputy Chairman from among its members.

title: Vacation and Resignation of Office (Article 183)
description: The Chairman or Deputy Chairman may resign, be removed, or vacate office upon ceasing to be a member.

title: Performance of Duties of Chairman (Article 184)
description: Deputy Chairman or a member appointed by the Governor performs duties when the Chairman’s office is vacant.

title: Restriction During Removal Proceedings (Article 185)
description: The Chairman or Deputy Chairman shall not preside while a resolution for removal is under consideration.

title: Salaries and Allowances of Presiding Officers (Article 186)
description: Salaries and allowances of presiding officers are charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State.

title: Secretariat of State Legislature (Article 187)
description: Each House of the State Legislature shall have a separate secretarial staff regulated by law.

title: Oath or Affirmation by Members (Article 188)
description: Every member of the State Legislature shall take an oath or affirmation before taking their seat.
punishment: Cannot sit or vote without oath.

title: Voting in the Legislature (Article 189)
description: All questions in a House shall be determined by a majority of members present and voting; presiding officer has casting vote.

title: Vacation of Seats (Article 190)
description: A member shall vacate his seat if disqualified, resigns, or is absent without permission for 60 days.

title: Disqualifications for Membership (Article 191)
description: A person is disqualified if holding office of profit, unsound mind, insolvent, or disqualified by law.

title: Decision on Disqualification (Article 192)
description: The Governor decides questions of disqualification after consulting the Election Commission.

title: Penalty for Unauthorized Sitting or Voting (Article 193)
description: A person sitting or voting without taking oath or when disqualified shall be liable to a fine.

title: Legislative Privileges (Article 194)
description: State Legislature members enjoy freedom of speech and other privileges similar to Parliament.
punishment: Protection from legal action for legislative speech.

title: Salaries and Allowances of Members (Article 195)
description: Members of State Legislature are entitled to salaries and allowances as determined by law.

title: Introduction and Passing of Bills (Article 196)
description: A Bill may originate in either House except Money Bills which originate only in Legislative Assembly.

title: Restriction on Legislative Council (Article 197)
