description: Legislative Council can delay but not reject Money Bills passed by Legislative Assembly.

title: Special Procedure for Money Bills (Article 198)
description: Money Bills passed by the Legislative Assembly are transmitted to the Legislative Council, which must return them within the prescribed time.

title: Money Bills Defined (Article 199)
description: A Bill is a Money Bill if it contains provisions related to taxation, borrowing, expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of the State.

title: Assent to Bills by Governor (Article 200)
description: When a Bill is presented, the Governor may give assent, withhold assent, return it, or reserve it for President’s consideration.

title: President’s Assent to Reserved Bills (Article 201)
description: When a Bill is reserved, the President may assent or withhold assent or return it to the State Legislature.

title: Annual Financial Statement (Article 202)
description: The Governor shall lay before the State Legislature the Annual Financial Statement (State Budget).

title: Procedure for Estimates (Article 203)
description: Estimates of expenditure must be voted by the Legislative Assembly and cannot be voted upon by the Legislative Council.

title: Appropriation Bills (Article 204)
description: No money shall be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund except under an Appropriation Act.

title: Supplementary and Excess Grants (Article 205)
description: Provision for additional or excess expenditure not included in the Annual Financial Statement.

title: Votes on Account and Credit (Article 206)
description: The Legislative Assembly may grant votes on account for urgent expenditure.

title: Special Provisions for Financial Bills (Article 207)
description: Financial Bills require the Governor’s recommendation before introduction.

title: Rules of Procedure (Article 208)
description: Each House of the State Legislature may make rules for regulating its procedure and conduct of business.

title: Procedure Regulation by Law (Article 209)
description: The Legislature may regulate its procedure by law until rules are framed.

title: Language of State Legislature (Article 210)
description: Business in the Legislature shall be conducted in the official language or Hindi or English as authorized.

title: Restriction on Discussion (Article 211)
description: No discussion shall take place in the Legislature regarding the conduct of judges of Supreme Court or High Court.

title: Courts and Legislative Proceedings (Article 212)
description: Courts shall not inquire into proceedings of the State Legislature for procedural irregularities.

title: Ordinance-making Power of the Governor (Article 213)
description: When the State Legislature is not in session and circumstances require immediate action, the Governor may promulgate Ordinances having the same force as an Act of the Legislature.
punishment: Ordinance ceases to operate six weeks after reassembly unless approved.

title: High Courts for States (Article 214)
description: There shall be a High Court for each State of India.

title: High Court as Court of Record (Article 215)
description: Every High Court shall be a court of record and shall have power to punish for contempt of itself.

title: Constitution of High Courts (Article 216)
description: Every High Court shall consist of a Chief Justice and such other Judges as the President may appoint.

title: Appointment and Conditions of High Court Judges (Article 217)
description: Judges of High Courts are appointed by the President after consultation and hold office till age of 62 years.

title: Application of SC Judge Provisions to HC Judges (Article 218)
description: Provisions relating to removal, salaries, and privileges of Supreme Court judges apply to High Court judges.
punishment: Same removal procedure as SC judges.

title: Oath or Affirmation by High Court Judges (Article 219)
description: Every Judge of a High Court shall take an oath before the Governor of the State.

title: Restriction on Practice (Article 220)
description: A retired High Court judge shall not plead or act in any court except the Supreme Court and other High Courts.

title: Salaries and Allowances of High Court Judges (Article 221)
description: Judges of High Courts shall receive salaries and pensions as determined by Parliament and charged on Consolidated Fund.

title: Transfer of High Court Judges (Article 222)
description: The President may transfer a Judge from one High Court to another after consultation with the Chief Justice of India.

title: Acting Chief Justice (Article 223)
description: When the office of Chief Justice is vacant, the President appoints an Acting Chief Justice.

title: Additional and Acting Judges (Article 224)
description: The President may appoint Additional or Acting Judges for temporary increase in workload or vacancy.

title: Additional and Acting Judges (Article 224)
description: The President may appoint Additional or Acting Judges for temporary increase in workload or vacancy.

title: Appointment of Retired Judges (Article 224A)
description: The Chief Justice of a High Court may request retired judges to sit and act as judges.

title: Jurisdiction of High Courts (Article 225)
description: Jurisdiction of existing High Courts remains as before unless altered by law.

title: Writ Jurisdiction of High Courts (Article 226)
description: High Courts may issue writs for enforcement of Fundamental Rights and for any other purpose.

title: Superintendence of High Courts (Article 227)
description: Every High Court has superintendence over all courts and tribunals within its jurisdiction.

title: Transfer of Cases to High Court (Article 228)
description: The High Court may withdraw a case involving substantial constitutional questions from a subordinate court.

title: Officers and Servants of High Courts (Article 229)
description: Appointments and service conditions of High Court staff are controlled by the Chief Justice of the High Court.

title: Extension of High Court Jurisdiction (Article 230)
description: Parliament may extend the jurisdiction of a High Court to Union Territories.

title: Common High Court for Two or More States (Article 231)
description: Parliament may establish a common High Court for two or more States or Union Territories.

title: Appointment of District Judges (Article 233)
description: Appointments, postings, and promotions of district judges are made by the Governor in consultation with the High Court.
punishment: Invalid appointments can be challenged constitutionally.

title: Validation of District Judge Appointments (Article 233A)
description: Validates appointments of district judges made before the commencement of the Constitution (Twentieth Amendment) Act, 1966.

title: Recruitment of Judicial Officers (Article 234)
description: Appointments of persons other than district judges to the judicial service are made by the Governor in consultation with the High Court and Public Service Commission.

title: Control of High Court Over Subordinate Courts (Article 235)
description: The High Court has control over district courts and courts subordinate thereto, including disciplinary matters.

title: Interpretation of Subordinate Courts Provisions (Article 236)
description: Defines terms such as 'district judge' and 'judicial service' for this Chapter.

title: Application of Provisions to Magistrates (Article 237)
description: The Governor may apply provisions of this Chapter to magistrates as deemed appropriate.

title: Part B States (Article 238) – Repealed
description: This Article relating to Part B States was repealed by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

title: Administration of Union Territories (Article 239)
description: Union Territories are administered by the President through an Administrator appointed by him.

title: Legislature or Council of Ministers for Certain Union Territories (Article 239A)
description: Parliament may create legislatures or councils of ministers for certain Union Territories.

title: Special Status of Delhi (Article 239AA)
description: Provides for a Legislative Assembly and Council of Ministers for the National Capital Territory of Delhi.

title: President’s Rule in Union Territories (Article 239AB)
description: Allows the President to suspend operation of Article 239AA in case of constitutional failure in Delhi.

title: Ordinance Powers in Union Territories (Article 239B)
description: Administrator may promulgate ordinances when the legislature is not in session.

title: President’s Regulation-making Power (Article 240)
description: President may make regulations for peace, progress, and good governance of certain Union Territories.

title: High Courts for Union Territories (Article 241)
description: Parliament may establish High Courts or extend jurisdiction of High Courts to Union Territories.

title: Coorg (Article 242) – Repealed
description: This Article relating to the State of Coorg was repealed by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

title: Definitions (Article 243)
description: Defines key terms such as Panchayat, Gram Sabha, village, district, and population for Part IX.

title: Gram Sabha (Article 243A)
description: Gram Sabha consists of all registered voters in a village and exercises powers as provided by State law.

title: Constitution of Panchayats (Article 243B)
description: Provides for Panchayats at village, intermediate, and district levels in every State.

title: Composition of Panchayats (Article 243C)
description: Members of Panchayats are elected directly; Chairpersons elected as per State law.

title: Reservation in Panchayats (Article 243D)
description: Reserves seats for SCs, STs, and women (not less than one-third) in Panchayats.

title: Duration of Panchayats (Article 243E)
description: Every Panchayat shall continue for five years unless dissolved earlier.

title: Disqualification of Members (Article 243F)
description: Provides grounds for disqualification of Panchayat members under State law.

title: Powers of Panchayats (Article 243G)
description: States may endow Panchayats with powers to function as institutions of self-government.

title: Financial Powers of Panchayats (Article 243H)
description: Panchayats may levy, collect, and appropriate taxes, duties, tolls, and fees.

title: State Finance Commission (Article 243I)
description: Governor constitutes a Finance Commission every five years to review Panchayat finances.

title: Audit of Panchayat Accounts (Article 243J)
description: State Legislature may provide for audit of Panchayat accounts.

title: Panchayat Elections (Article 243K)
description: Elections are conducted under the supervision of the State Election Commission.

title: Application to Union Territories (Article 243L)
description: Provisions of Part IX apply to Union Territories with modifications.

title: Exemptions from Part IX (Article 243M)
description: Certain areas like Scheduled Areas and tribal regions are exempted.

title: Continuance of Existing Laws (Article 243N)
description: Existing Panchayat laws continue until amended or repealed.

title: Bar on Court Interference (Article 243O)
description: Courts cannot interfere in Panchayat electoral matters except through election petitions.

title: Definitions (Article 243P)
description: Defines terms such as Municipality, Municipal area, Nagar Panchayat, Municipal Council, and Municipal Corporation.

title: Constitution of Municipalities (Article 243Q)
description: Municipalities are constituted in urban areas based on population and development level.

title: Composition of Municipalities (Article 243R)
description: Members are directly elected; State Legislature may include nominated members without voting rights.

title: Wards Committees (Article 243S)
description: Wards Committees are constituted in municipalities with population above a specified limit.

title: Reservation in Municipalities (Article 243T)
description: Provides reservation for SCs, STs, and women (not less than one-third) in Municipal bodies.

title: Duration of Municipalities (Article 243U)
description: Municipalities have a term of five years unless dissolved earlier.

title: Disqualification of Members (Article 243V)
description: Grounds for disqualification of municipal members are prescribed by State law.

title: Powers of Municipalities (Article 243W)
description: States may endow Municipalities with powers to function as institutions of self-government.

title: Financial Powers of Municipalities (Article 243X)
description: Municipalities may levy and collect taxes, duties, tolls, and fees.

title: Finance Commission for Municipalities (Article 243Y)
description: State Finance Commission reviews financial position of Municipalities every five years.

title: Audit of Municipal Accounts (Article 243Z)
description: State Legislature may provide for audit of Municipal accounts.

title: Municipal Elections (Article 243ZA)
description: Municipal elections are conducted by the State Election Commission.

title: Application to Union Territories (Article 243ZB)
description: Provisions of Part IXA apply to Union Territories with modifications.

title: Exemptions from Part IXA (Article 243ZC)
description: Certain areas like Scheduled Areas and tribal regions are exempted.

title: District Planning Committee (Article 243ZD)
description: District Planning Committees consolidate plans prepared by Panchayats and Municipalities.

title: Metropolitan Planning Committee (Article 243ZE)
description: Metropolitan Planning Committees prepare development plans for metropolitan areas.

title: Continuance of Existing Laws (Article 243ZF)
description: Existing municipal laws continue until amended or repealed.

title: Bar on Court Interference (Article 243ZG)
description: Courts cannot interfere in municipal election matters except through election petitions.

title: Definitions (Article 243ZH)
description: Defines terms such as co-operative society, board, office bearer, and member for Part IXB.

title: Incorporation of Co-operative Societies (Article 243ZI)
description: State Legislature may make laws for incorporation, regulation, and winding up of co-operative societies.

title: Board Members and Tenure (Article 243ZJ)
description: Fixes maximum number of directors and a five-year term for the board of co-operative societies.

title: Election of Co-operative Board (Article 243ZK)
description: Elections to the board shall be conducted before expiry of the term.

title: Supersession of Co-operative Board (Article 243ZL)
description: Board may be superseded for a limited period under specified conditions.

title: Audit of Co-operative Societies (Article 243ZM)
description: Accounts of co-operative societies shall be audited by qualified auditors.

title: General Body Meetings (Article 243ZN)
description: Annual General Body Meeting must be convened within a prescribed period.

title: Right to Information (Article 243ZO)
description: Members have access to information relating to the functioning of co-operative societies.

title: Submission of Returns (Article 243ZP)
description: Co-operative societies must submit annual returns to authorities.

title: Offences in Co-operative Societies (Article 243ZQ)
description: State law may specify offences and penalties for co-operative societies.

title: Multi-State Co-operative Societies (Article 243ZR)
description: Provisions apply to multi-state co-operative societies subject to Central law.

title: Application to Union Territories (Article 243ZS)
description: Provisions of Part IXB apply to Union Territories with modifications.

title: Continuance of Existing Laws (Article 243ZT)
description: Existing co-operative laws continue until amended or repealed.

title: Administration of Scheduled and Tribal Areas (Article 244)
description: Provides that Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas shall be administered in accordance with the Fifth and Sixth Schedules of the Constitution.

title: Autonomous State in Assam (Article 244A)
description: Parliament may form an autonomous State within Assam comprising certain tribal areas and provide for a legislature or council of ministers.

title: Extent of Laws (Article 245)
description: Parliament may make laws for the whole or any part of India; State Legislatures may make laws for their respective States.

title: Distribution of Legislative Powers (Article 246)
description: Divides legislative subjects into Union List, State List, and Concurrent List under the Seventh Schedule.

title: Special Provision for Goods and Services Tax (Article 246A)
description: Parliament and State Legislatures have concurrent powers to make laws regarding GST.

title: Power to Establish Additional Courts (Article 247)
description: Parliament may establish courts for better administration of laws made by it.

title: Residuary Powers (Article 248)
description: Parliament has exclusive power to legislate on matters not enumerated in any list.

title: Parliament’s Power in National Interest (Article 249)
description: Parliament may legislate on State List matters if Rajya Sabha passes a resolution in national interest.

title: Parliament’s Power During Emergency (Article 250)
description: Parliament may legislate on State List matters during a national emergency.

title: Union Law Prevails in Case of Conflict (Article 251)
description: Union law prevails over State law on matters under Articles 249 and 250.

title: Parliament’s Power with State Consent (Article 252)
description: Parliament may legislate for two or more States with their consent on State List matters.

title: Legislation for International Treaties (Article 253)
description: Parliament may make laws to implement international treaties and agreements.

title: Repugnancy Between Union and State Laws (Article 254)
description: Union law prevails over State law in case of inconsistency in Concurrent List matters.
punishment: Union law supremacy unless President assents.

title: Procedural Requirements for Certain Bills (Article 255)
description: Failure to comply with recommendation requirements does not invalidate an Act.

title: Obligation of States and Union (Article 256)
description: States must ensure compliance with laws made by Parliament; the Union may give directions to States.

title: Union Control over States (Article 257)
description: Union may give directions to States regarding national importance and communication infrastructure.

title: Delegation of Union Functions (Article 258)
description: Union may entrust its executive functions to States with consent.

title: Delegation of State Functions to Union (Article 258A)
description: States may entrust their executive functions to the Union.

title: Armed Forces in Aid of Civil Power (Article 259) – Repealed
description: This Article relating to armed forces assistance was repealed by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

title: Jurisdiction Outside India (Article 260)
description: Union may exercise jurisdiction outside India as per agreements with foreign countries.

title: Public Acts and Judicial Proceedings (Article 261)
description: Full faith and credit shall be given to public acts, records, and judicial proceedings throughout India.

title: Water Dispute Adjudication (Article 262)
description: Parliament may provide for adjudication of inter-State river water disputes.

title: Inter-State Council (Article 263)
description: President may establish an Inter-State Council for coordination between States and the Union.

title: Interpretation (Article 264)
description: Defines terms used in Part XII relating to finance.

title: Interpretation (Article 264)
description: Defines terms used in Part XII relating to finance.

title: Levy and Collection of Taxes (Article 265)
description: No tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law.

title: Consolidated Fund and Public Account (Article 266)
description: Establishes Consolidated Fund and Public Account of India and States.

title: Contingency Fund (Article 267)
description: Provides for Contingency Funds for India and States to meet unforeseen expenditure.

title: Stamp Duties (Article 268)
description: Stamp duties are levied by the Union but collected and appropriated by the States.

title: Assigned Taxes (Article 269)
description: Certain taxes are levied and collected by the Union but assigned to States.

title: IGST Provision (Article 269A)
description: GST on inter-State supplies is levied and collected by the Union and apportioned between Union and States.

title: Distribution of Taxes (Article 270)
description: Taxes collected by the Union are distributed between Union and States.

title: Surcharge on Taxes (Article 271)
description: Parliament may levy surcharge on certain taxes for Union purposes.

title: Distribution of Taxes (Article 272) – Repealed
description: This Article was repealed by the Constitution (Eighty-eighth Amendment) Act, 2003.

title: Grants in Lieu of Export Duties (Article 273)
description: Provides for grants to States in lieu of export duties on jute and jute products.

title: Recommendation for Financial Bills (Article 274)
description: Certain financial bills affecting State taxation require prior Presidential recommendation.

title: Grants from Union to States (Article 275)
description: Union may make grants to States in need of assistance.

title: Income Tax (Article 276)
description: Provides for the levy of income tax by the Union and its collection and appropriation between Union and States.

title: Savings of Existing Taxes (Article 277)
description: Existing taxes at the commencement of the Constitution continue until Parliament provides otherwise.

title: Agreements with States (Article 278) – Repealed
description: This Article was repealed by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

title: Net Proceeds of Taxes (Article 279)
description: Defines how net proceeds of taxes are calculated for distribution.

title: GST Council (Article 279A)
description: Establishes the GST Council to make recommendations on GST matters.

title: Finance Commission (Article 280)
description: President constitutes a Finance Commission every five years to recommend revenue distribution.

title: Finance Commission Reports (Article 281)
description: Recommendations of the Finance Commission are laid before Parliament.

title: Finance Commission Reports (Article 281)
description: Recommendations of the Finance Commission are laid before Parliament.

title: Public Expenditure (Article 282)
description: Union or State may make grants for any public purpose.

title: Custody of Funds (Article 283)
description: Provides for custody and operation of Consolidated and Public Account funds.

title: Suitors’ Deposits (Article 284)
description: Deals with custody of deposits made in courts.

title: Exemption from Taxation (Article 285)
description: Union property is exempt from State taxation unless Parliament provides otherwise.

title: Restrictions on State Taxation (Article 286)
description: States cannot tax inter-State or international trade sales.

title: Electricity Tax Exemption (Article 287)
description: Union property is exempt from State electricity tax.

title: Electricity Tax Exemption (Article 287)
description: Union property is exempt from State electricity tax.

title: Water and Electricity Tax Exemption (Article 288)
description: State taxation on water or electricity used by Union requires Presidential consent.

title: State Property Tax Exemption (Article 289)
description: State property is exempt from Union taxation except for commercial activities.

title: Adjustment of Expenses (Article 290)
description: Provides for adjustment of certain expenses between Union and States.

title: Devaswom Fund Grants (Article 290A)
description: Provides grants to Devaswom Funds in Kerala and Tamil Nadu.

title: Privy Purse (Article 291) – Repealed
description: This Article relating to privy purses was repealed by the Constitution (Twenty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1971.

title: Borrowing by the Union (Article 292)
description: The Government of India may borrow money upon the security of the Consolidated Fund of India within limits fixed by Parliament.

title: Borrowing by States (Article 293)
description: States may borrow within India subject to limits imposed by their legislatures and with Union consent if indebted to the Union.

title: Succession to Property and Liabilities (Article 294)
description: Property, assets, rights, liabilities, and obligations of the Government of India and States succeed as per constitutional allocation.

title: Succession in Special Cases (Article 295)
description: Provides succession of property and liabilities relating to Indian States integrated into India.

title: Escheat or Lapse (Article 296)
description: Property without a legal owner shall vest in the Union or the State as per jurisdiction.

title: Territorial Waters and Resources (Article 297)
description: All lands, minerals, and resources under ocean waters vest in the Union of India.

title: Trade and Business Powers (Article 298)
description: Union and States may carry on trade, business, and make contracts for any purpose.

title: Government Contracts (Article 299)
description: Contracts made in the exercise of executive power must be expressed in the name of the President or Governor.
punishment: Invalid if constitutional procedure not followed.

title: Suits by or Against Government (Article 300)
description: The Government of India and States may sue or be sued as per law.

title: Right to Property (Article 300A)
description: No person shall be deprived of property except by authority of law.

title: Freedom of Trade, Commerce and Intercourse
description: Trade, commerce and intercourse throughout the territory of India shall be free.

title: Power of Parliament to Impose Restrictions
description: Parliament may impose reasonable restrictions on the freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse in the public interest.

title: Restriction on Discriminatory Legislation
description: Neither Parliament nor State Legislatures shall make laws giving preference to one State over another, except to deal with scarcity of goods.

title: Restrictions on Trade by States
description: States may impose non-discriminatory taxes on goods from other States and reasonable restrictions in public interest with prior Presidential sanction.

title: Saving of Existing Laws
description: Existing laws relating to trade, commerce and intercourse are protected even if inconsistent with Article 301.

title: Special Provisions (Omitted)
description: This article provided special provisions for certain States and has been repealed.

title: Appointment of Authority for Trade Regulation
description: Parliament may appoint an authority to carry out the purposes of Articles 301 to 304.
This Part applies to persons appointed to public services and posts in connection with the affairs of the Union or of any State.
Parliament or State Legislature may regulate the recruitment and conditions of service of persons serving the Union or a State.
Every person serving the Union or a State holds office during the pleasure of the President or the Governor respectively.
No civil servant shall be dismissed, removed, or reduced in rank without an inquiry and reasonable opportunity of being heard.
Parliament may create All-India Services common to the Union and the States if the Rajya Sabha passes a resolution.
Parliament may vary or revoke conditions of service of officers of All-India Services.
Existing laws relating to public services shall continue in force until altered or repealed.
This article relating to protection of certain public servants has been repealed.
There shall be a Public Service Commission for the Union and for each State.
Appointment and tenure of members of the Public Service Commission shall be governed by constitutional provisions.
Members of a Public Service Commission may be removed only on specific grounds and by prescribed procedure.
The President or Governor may make regulations regarding conditions of service of PSC members.
Restrictions are placed on future employment of members after leaving the Public Service Commission.
Public Service Commissions shall be consulted on matters of recruitment and service conditions.
Parliament or State Legislature may extend the functions of Public Service Commissions.
Expenses of the Public Service Commission shall be charged on the Consolidated Fund.
Public Service Commissions shall present annual reports to the President or the Governor.
Parliament may provide for the establishment of Administrative Tribunals for adjudication of disputes related to recruitment and conditions of service of public servants.
Parliament and State Legislatures may provide for the establishment of tribunals for matters such as taxation, industrial disputes, land reforms, and elections.

Provides for levy of stamp duty on instruments and legal documents.

Regulates working conditions, health, safety, and welfare of workers in factories.

title: First Schedule
description: Lists the States and Union Territories of India and their territorial extent.

title: Second Schedule
description: Deals with salaries, allowances, and privileges of constitutional authorities.

title: Third Schedule
description: Contains forms of oaths and affirmations for constitutional offices.

title: Fourth Schedule
description: Provides allocation of seats in the Rajya Sabha to States and Union Territories.

title: Fifth Schedule
description: Administration and control of Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes.

title: Sixth Schedule
description: Administration of tribal areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram.

title: Seventh Schedule
description: Division of powers between Union, State, and Concurrent Lists.

title: Eighth Schedule
description: Lists the official languages recognized by the Constitution.

title: Ninth Schedule
description: Protects certain laws from judicial review.

title: Tenth Schedule
description: Contains provisions relating to disqualification of legislators on grounds of defection.

title: Eleventh Schedule
description: Lists subjects under the Panchayati Raj Institutions.

title: Twelfth Schedule
description: Lists subjects under Municipalities.

title: First Constitutional Amendment Act, 1951
description: Added reasonable restrictions to Fundamental Rights and protected land reform laws by introducing the Ninth Schedule.
impact: Limited absolute Fundamental Rights in public interest.

title: Second Constitutional Amendment Act, 1952
description: Adjusted representation of states in Parliament.

title: Third Constitutional Amendment Act, 1954
description: Modified allocation of seats in State Legislative Councils.

title: Fourth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1955
description: Restricted property rights and amended compensation provisions.

title: Fifth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1955
description: Provided procedure for consultation with states regarding boundary changes.

title: Sixth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1956
description: Amended taxation provisions related to interstate trade and commerce.

title: Seventh Constitutional Amendment Act, 1956
description: Implemented States Reorganisation and restructured Union and State territories.

title: Eighth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1960
description: Extended reservation of seats for SCs and STs in legislatures.

title: Ninth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1960
description: Added land reform laws to the Ninth Schedule.

title: Tenth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1961
description: Incorporated Dadra and Nagar Haveli into the Indian Union.

title: Eleventh Constitutional Amendment Act, 1961

title: Twelfth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1962
description: Incorporated the territories of Goa, Daman and Diu into the Indian Union.

title: Thirteenth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1962
description: Provided special status to the State of Nagaland under Article 371A.

title: Fourteenth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1962

impact: Expanded democratic governance in Union Territories.

title: Fifteenth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1963
description: Raised the retirement age of High Court judges from 60 to 62 years.

title: Sixteenth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1963

title: Seventeenth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1964
description: Added more land reform laws to the Ninth Schedule.
impact: Protected agrarian reform laws from judicial review.

title: Eighteenth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1966

title: Nineteenth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1966

title: Twentieth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1966

title: Twenty-Third Constitutional Amendment Act, 1969

title: Twenty-Fourth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1971

title: Twenty-Fifth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1971

impact: Reduced judicial scrutiny over property acquisition.

title: Twenty-Sixth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1971

title: Twenty-Seventh Constitutional Amendment Act, 1971

title: Twenty-Eighth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1972

title: Twenty-Ninth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1972

title: Thirty-Third Constitutional Amendment Act, 1974

title: Thirty-Seventh Constitutional Amendment Act, 1975

title: Thirty-Eighth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1975

title: Thirty-Ninth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1975
description: Placed election disputes of key constitutional offices beyond judicial scrutiny.

title: Fortieth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976
description: Placed certain central and state laws in the Ninth Schedule.

title: Forty-First Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976
description: Raised retirement age of Chairmen and Members of Tribunals.

title: Forty-Second Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976

title: Forty-Third Constitutional Amendment Act, 1977
description: Restored judicial review curtailed by the 42nd Amendment.

title: Forty-Fourth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1978

title: Forty-Fifth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1980

title: Forty-Sixth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1982
description: Allowed states to tax sale of goods in specific cases.

title: Forty-Seventh Constitutional Amendment Act, 1984
description: Added land reform laws to the Ninth Schedule.

title: Forty-Eighth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1984
description: Extended President’s Rule in Punjab.

title: Forty-Ninth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1984
description: Provided reservation of seats for Tripura Tribal Areas.

title: Fiftieth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1984
description: Exempted certain service posts from UPSC consultation.

title: Fifty-First Constitutional Amendment Act, 1984
description: Provided reservation of seats for SCs and STs in Meghalaya, Nagaland, Arunachal Pradesh, and Mizoram.

title: Fifty-Second Constitutional Amendment Act, 1985
description: Introduced the Anti-Defection Law through the Tenth Schedule.

title: Fifty-Third Constitutional Amendment Act, 1986

title: Fifty-Fourth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1986
description: Increased salaries of Supreme Court and High Court judges.

title: Fifty-Fifth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1986
description: Provided special provisions for Arunachal Pradesh under Article 371H.

title: Fifty-Sixth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1987

title: Fifty-Seventh Constitutional Amendment Act, 1987
description: Extended reservation of seats for SCs and STs in legislatures.

title: Fifty-Eighth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1987

title: Fifty-Ninth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1988

title: Sixty-First Constitutional Amendment Act, 1989
description: Reduced voting age from 21 to 18 years.

title: Sixty-Second Constitutional Amendment Act, 1989
description: Extended reservation of seats for SCs and STs.

description: Repealed the special provisions related to Punjab Emergency.

title: Sixty-Fourth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1990
description: Extended President’s Rule in Punjab.

title: Sixty-Fifth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1990

title: Sixty-Sixth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1990

title: Sixty-Seventh Constitutional Amendment Act, 1990
description: Extended reservation of seats for SCs and STs.

description: Provided special status to the National Capital Territory of Delhi.

description: Allowed inclusion of Union Territories in Presidential elections.

description: Provided for Rent Control Tribunals.

title: Seventy-Ninth Constitutional Amendment Act, 1999

title: President Powers and Functions
description: Defines executive authority, veto powers, ordinance powers, and emergency roles of the President.
impact: Clarifies constitutional executive authority and governance structure.

description: Explains leadership of government, collective responsibility, and executive decision-making.
impact: Defines real operational control of the Union Government.

title: Parliament Law-Making Process
description: Covers bill introduction, debate, voting, assent, and legislative procedure.
impact: Explains how laws are created and enforced.

title: Money Bill vs Ordinary Bill
description: Distinguishes financial legislation from general laws and explains passage procedure.

description: Defines original, appellate, and advisory jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
impact: Ensures understanding of highest judicial authority.

title: High Court and Subordinate Courts
description: Explains structure and authority of state-level judiciary.

title: Centre-State Legislative Relations
description: Defines division of powers using Union, State, and Concurrent Lists.

title: Local Government Structure

title: Basic Structure Doctrine
description: Prevents Parliament from altering core constitutional principles.
impact: Protects democratic framework and constitutional identity.

title: Judicial Review
description: Allows courts to examine constitutionality of laws and executive actions.

title: Doctrine of Severability
description: Invalidates only unconstitutional parts of a law without striking entire statute.

title: Doctrine of Pith and Substance
description: Determines true nature of legislation for jurisdictional conflicts.

title: Harmonious Construction
description: Interprets constitutional provisions to avoid conflicts between them.

title: Expansion of Article 21
description: Judicial interpretation expanded right to life to include dignity, privacy, and liberty.

title: Right to Privacy Jurisprudence
description: Recognised privacy as a fundamental constitutional right.
impact: Influenced digital rights and data protection.

title: Free Speech and Online Expression
description: Defined constitutional limits and protections of digital speech.

title: Public Interest Litigation Evolution
description: Expanded access to justice through PIL mechanisms.
impact: Enabled citizen participation in constitutional enforcement.

title: Judicial Independence and Appointments
description: Defined role of judiciary in appointment and autonomy issues.

title: Election Commission Functions
description: Regulates elections, political parties, and voting processes.
impact: Ensures free and fair democratic elections.

title: CAG and Public Financial Oversight
description: Audits government accounts and public spending.

title: UPSC and Civil Services Recruitment
description: Conducts recruitment for public services and administrative posts.

title: Anti-Defection Law
description: Regulates political party switching by elected representatives.

title: Ordinance Making Power
description: Allows temporary laws when legislature is not in session.

title: Finance Commission Functions
description: Recommends financial distribution between Union and States.

title: NITI Aayog Policy Role
description: Policy think tank guiding economic planning and development strategies.

title: Central Vigilance Commission
description: Supervises anti-corruption measures in government administration.

title: Lokpal and Anti-Corruption Mechanism
description: Independent authority investigating corruption allegations against public officials.

title: RTI Implementation Framework
description: Operational process for citizens requesting government information.

title: Separation of Powers
description: Division of governmental responsibilities among Legislature, Executive, and Judiciary to prevent concentration of power.
impact: Maintains checks and balances and ensures accountability in governance.

title: Federal Structure of India
description: Division of powers between Union and State governments through Union, State, and Concurrent Lists.
impact: Ensures balanced distribution of authority across levels of government.

title: Parliamentary Form of Government
description: Executive is responsible to the Legislature and functions through the Council of Ministers headed by the Prime Minister.
impact: Promotes democratic accountability and collective responsibility.

title: Bicameral Legislature
description: Structure of Parliament consisting of Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha with distinct roles and powers.
impact: Ensures representation of people and states in lawmaking.

title: Independent Judiciary
description: Judiciary functions independently from executive and legislative influence to uphold the Constitution.
impact: Protects Fundamental Rights and ensures rule of law.

title: Single Citizenship
description: Provides one citizenship for all Indians regardless of state affiliation.
impact: Promotes national unity and equal legal status.

title: Integrated Judicial System
description: Unified court structure with Supreme Court at the top followed by High Courts and subordinate courts.
impact: Ensures uniformity in law interpretation across the country.

title: Emergency Provisions Framework
description: Structural mechanism allowing the Union to assume greater powers during national, state, or financial emergencies.
impact: Maintains stability and national security during crises.

title: Council of Ministers System
description: Executive authority exercised through the Council of Ministers collectively responsible to Lok Sabha.
impact: Ensures democratic accountability of executive decisions.

title: Role of the President
description: Constitutional head of the State with executive, legislative, and emergency powers.
impact: Provides constitutional balance and ceremonial leadership.

title: Role of the Prime Minister
description: Head of the government responsible for policy direction and functioning of executive.
impact: Central leadership in governance and administration.

title: Role of Governors in States
description: Constitutional heads of states acting as link between Union and State governments.
impact: Maintains federal coordination and constitutional oversight.

title: Local Self-Government Structure
description: Panchayati Raj and Municipal governance systems at local levels.

title: Election Commission Structure
description: Independent constitutional body responsible for conducting free and fair elections.

title: Emergency Provisions Operational Structure
description: Explains National, State, and Financial Emergency mechanisms and power shifts.
impact: Defines crisis governance and constitutional control measures.

title: Centre-State Financial Relations
description: Distribution of taxes, grants, and fiscal responsibilities between Union and States.
impact: Maintains financial balance in federal governance.

title: Inter-State Council and Coordination Mechanisms
description: Structures that facilitate cooperation and dispute resolution between states.

title: Administrative Tribunals Structure
description: Specialized judicial bodies for service and administrative disputes.

title: Doctrine of Colourable Legislation
description: Prevents legislature from indirectly doing what it cannot do directly.

title: Doctrine of Eclipse
description: Pre-constitutional laws inconsistent with Fundamental Rights remain dormant until conflict removed.

title: Doctrine of Waiver
description: Determines whether individuals can waive Fundamental Rights protections.

title: Doctrine of Territorial Nexus
description: Allows laws to apply beyond territory if sufficient connection exists.

title: Prospective Overruling
description: Court decisions apply only to future cases without disturbing past actions.
impact: Ensures legal stability during major rulings.

description: Established the Basic Structure Doctrine limiting Parliament’s amendment power.

title: Maneka Gandhi Case (1978)
description: Expanded Article 21 to include due process and procedural fairness.

title: Minerva Mills Case (1980)
description: Balanced Fundamental Rights and Directive Principles.

title: Vishaka Guidelines Case (1997)
description: Established workplace sexual harassment guidelines before legislation existed.

title: Puttaswamy Case (2017)
description: Recognised Right to Privacy as a Fundamental Right.
impact: Influenced digital rights and data protection laws.

title: Finance Commission Functions
description: Recommends financial distribution between Union and States.

title: NITI Aayog Policy Role
description: Policy think tank guiding economic planning and development strategies.

title: Central Vigilance Commission
description: Supervises anti-corruption measures in government administration.

title: Lokpal and Anti-Corruption Mechanism
description: Independent authority investigating corruption allegations against public officials.

title: RTI Implementation Framework
description: Operational process for citizens requesting government information.

title: Public Service Commissions Structure

title: Doctrine of Legitimate Expectation

title: Doctrine of Proportionality

title: E-Governance and Digital Administration

title: Doctrine of Basic Structure

description: Prevents legislature from doing indirectly what it cannot do directly.

title: Doctrine of Eclipse
description: Pre-constitutional laws violating fundamental rights become inactive but not void.
impact: Allows revival of laws if constitutional conflicts are removed.

title: Doctrine of Severability
description: Only unconstitutional parts of a law are removed while valid parts remain.

title: Doctrine of Waiver
description: Individuals cannot voluntarily give up fundamental rights guaranteed by the Constitution.

title: Doctrine of Harmonious Construction

title: Doctrine of Territorial Nexus
description: State laws can apply outside territory if a sufficient connection exists.

title: Doctrine of Occupied Field
description: State laws cannot operate in areas fully covered by central legislation.
